p: Currently, amantadine, oseltamivir, and zanamivir are used for treatment of influenza A (Pica and Palese 2013), including inhibition of the matrix protein M2 (amantadine) and NA (oseltamivir and zanamivir). M2 ion channel blockers only inhibit IAV and have potential neurotoxicity (Zhao et al. 2012). Neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs) prevent infected cells from releasing and transmitting progeny virions during the replication cycle by binding to the active site of viral neuraminidase (Belser et al. 2015). However, in recent years, because of the widespread use of these drugs, resistant strains of IAV have emerged (Hurt et al. 2009; Moscona 2009; Cho et al. 2013). Therefore, it is urgent to identify new antiviral drugs that are effective against influenza viruses.
